Dear Jason M Lheureux:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code &
R 400.4109 Program statement.
Section
Rule 109. (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
Description
program statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety, and
supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was left unattended by Staff 1 in the VanderArk unit
which is a locked facility. This occurred on 01/29/24 at 12:55 PM
when Staff 1 clocked out of work.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via phone on 1/31/2024. She
reported being informed by Supervisor 2 of the allegations.
Supervisor 2 informed Complainant of returning to the unit and
finding Youth A alone in the milieu. There were no other staff or
youth on the unit which is a secure unit. Supervisor 2 also
informed Complainant that Staff 1 texted Supervisor 1 indicating
he was ill and needed to be relieved. Supervisor 1 texted back
that Staff 1 would need to wait until Supervisor 2 returned to the
unit. Complainant also reported Staff 1 did not wait until
Supervisor 2 returned and left work at 12:55 pm. Supervisor 2
found Youth A 10-minutes later when she came on the unit.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via phone on 1/31/2024.
Supervisor 2 reported being the staff that found Youth A in the
milieu alone and with no other staff or youth present. Youth A was
playing a video game when she walked into the milieu. She also
reported Staff 1 had informed Supervisor 1 that he had a fever
and needed to leave work. Supervisor 2 was interviewed again,
face to face at the facility on 2/1/2024 in collaboration with
MDHHS worker. Supervisor 2 reported being in the process of
dropping off medication to youth at school and when returning to
the milieu, finding Youth A alone, sitting on the couch playing a
video game. Supervisor 2 asked Youth A where Staff 1 was, and
Youth A said Staff 1 had a fever and left. Youth A also reported
Supervisor 1 was present but when Youth A looked into
Supervisor 1’s office (through a window in the door) Youth A found
no one in the office. Supervisor 2 reported knowing that
Supervisor 1 was off the unit and in a meeting. This is when
Supervisor 2 texted Supervisor 1 about the situation. Supervisor 2
reported leaving the unit at 12:30 to drop off medication and all
other staff knew she was leaving because she announced it prior
to leaving. Supervisor 2 also reported not being sure Youth A and
Staff 1 were on the unit at the time she made this announcement,
but she is sure Supervisor 1 was present. Supervisor 2 reported it
is policy to let others know if you are leaving and where you are
2

going. Text is the general method, and all staff have the ability to
text on different text treads. Supervisor 2 also reported being a
direct supervisor of Staff 1 at times and has had to speak to Staff
1 about paying close attention to what he is doing. She believes
Staff 1 is young and new at the job but has the ability to learn and
be a good staff. Supervisor 2 reported Staff 1’s interactions with
the youth are very positive.
Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on
2/1/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
being aware of the allegations. Administrator reported having no
pervious concerns about Staff 1’s employment because Staff 1
had been a “good employee”.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/1/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 1 reported beginning
his employment with the facility on October 2, 2023 and believed
the incident took place on 1/29/24 around 12:55 pm. Staff 1 had
taken Youth A to the nurse’s office and while there, Staff 1 had his
temperature checked. Staff 1 had not been feeling well throughout
the day and the nurse told Staff 1 he had a temperature. Staff 1
reported texting Supervisor 1 and informing Supervisor 1 of his
temperature and if he was still required to take Youth A on an
outing to purchase some clothing later in the day. Staff 1 also
informed Supervisor 1 that he was not feeling well and was
currently wearing a mask to keep from passing on his illness.
Supervisor 1 texted back the following “wait until Supervisor 2 gets
back and go home and get some rest”. Staff 1 reported he didn’t
read the beginning of the text but only the part about going home
and getting rest. Staff 1 finished some paperwork on the unit and
left the unit at 12:55pm, going through another exit so to avoid
getting other staff or youth exposed to his illness. Staff 1 believed
Supervisor 1 was in her office thus someone was on the unit
because he would “normally” wait to observe other staff with a
youth before leaving the area. He believed Supervisor 2 was also
on the unit. Staff 1 reported not hearing that Supervisor 1 would
be in a meeting. Staff 1 reported all the doors were locked on the
unit and Youth A did not have a safety plan requiring more than
the “normal 1 staff to 2 youth ratio”. Staff 1 reported making a
mistake and understands what he did was inappropriate. When
Staff 1 left Youth A, Youth A was sitting on the couch in the milieu
playing a video game.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
2/1/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Supervisor 1
reported being Staff 1’s direct supervisor and having no concerns
3

about his employment prior to this incident. She was not sure if
Staff 1 was present at the staff desk when she announced she
would be in a meeting in the “center” later in the day. Supervisor 1
reported Staff 1 was still somewhere in the milieu when the staff
desk meeting took place. When Supervisor 1 left the milieu for a
meeting she informed Staff 1 that she would be off the unit.
Supervisor 1 left for her meeting at 12:31pm and received a text
from Staff 1 at 12:37pm that he was leaving with Youth A to go to
the nursing office. Supervisor 1 reported receiving a second text
from Staff 1 at 12:38pm when he informed her of feeling ill. This is
when she sent the text telling him to wait for Supervisor 2 and
then go home. Supervisor 1 received a third text from Staff 1 at
12:48pm thanking her. Supervisor 1 received a text from
Supervisor 2 at 1:10pm that Supervisor 2 was back in the milieu
and found Youth A by himself. Supervisor 1 asked about the
location of Staff 1 and was informed by Supervisor 2 that Staff 1
had gone home. Supervisor 1 called Staff 1 and Staff 1 informed
her he had gone home and Supervisor 1 informed Staff 1 that she
had asked him to wait for Supervisor 2 before leaving. Staff 1 told
Supervisor 1 that he was sorry and had “messed up”. Supervisor 1
reported the expectations of staff are to let each other know what
is occurring and where the youth are at the time. She reported a
plan of disciplinary write up, future training on ratio and
supervision communication with additional shadow time.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
2/1/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A
reported feeling safe at the facility and he likes all of the staff.
Youth A reported Staff 1 took him to the nurse and left after they
returned to the milieu. Youth A reported Staff 1 was not feeling
well and had a fever. Youth A believed some other staff were
present in the office, when Staff 1 left to go home. Supervisor 2
came in later and asked Youth A where Staff 1 was, and he
informed Supervisor 2 that Staff 1 had left.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at school on 2/13/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported feeling safe
at the facility and well cared for by staff. He also reported having
no issues with staff and believes they are constantly supervising
the youth in the program.
Documents Reviewed:
Wedgwood Christian services – Significant Event Report
dated 1/30/24. This document outlines the incident that took place
with Youth A on 1/29/2024. It is documented Staff 2 walked into
4

the milieu on Vanderark and found Youth A without staff
supervision. Youth A was alone and reported to Staff 2, Staff 1
had gone home.
Wedgwood Christian services – Procedure for Client Safety
Procedures dated 7/13/2023. This document begins by stating
that when a youth is out of direct supervision by staff, variable
intervals checks of no more than 15-minutes must occur. These
checks must also be documented on the youth’s safety log.
Wedgwood Christian services – Residential Staffing Ratios
Procedures dated 7/13/2023. This document states, Direct care
staff are required to maintain line-of-sight supervision of youths at
all times except when youth are in their individual sleeping rooms
or bathroom.
Human Resources file for Staff 1 was reviewed. Staff 1 was
hired at the facility on 10/2/2023. Staff 1 completed orientation on
10/6/2023 and is current on all required trainings. The facility is in
the process of writing the disciplinary action for this incident.
Analysis Based upon interviews and written documentation there is
evidence that supports Staff 1 failed to provide the appropriate
level of supervision for Youth A by leaving the unit prior to any
other staff being present to supervise Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
